Dialogue.NPCText:
By the misty lake, a thin man in a broad straw hat sits beside a wooden bucket, humming and scratching brush on paper. He looks up, lines creasing into a gentle smile.

"Ah, a wanderer beside still waters. I am Bozu, fisherman by hand, poet by heart. Each catch is a verse, each loss a lesson.
What stirs your spirit today? The rod, the pen… or perhaps something hidden beneath the waves?"

Option.text: Do you have work for an adventurer?
Can you teach me to meditate like a true fisher?
I heard there are caves beneath the lake…

Dialogue.NPCText:
Bozu holds up a water-stained scroll.
"I write ishi no uta—death poems for fish. To honor the spirit of every catch, so that nothing is lost without song."

He recites, almost solemnly:
'Silver flash in dawn,
Ripple’s last dance, then silence.
May the lake remember.'

Option.text: That’s beautiful. Why write poems for fish?
What else have you seen on these waters?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Bozu smiles softly.
"Every life taken deserves memory. The old monks say this world is but a great sea, every ripple felt across lifetimes. A poem is a ripple, too—lasting longer than a fish’s breath."
"You seem thoughtful. If you bring me a rare fish, I will compose a verse for it—and for you."

Option.text: What rare fish do you seek?

Dialogue.NPCText:
"In these waters, legends swirl of the Moon-Scaled Koi. Only by night, when the moon is high, do they surface. Bring me such a koi, and I shall write a poem for both your names."
[Quest Started: Moon-Scaled Koi]

Option.text: I’ll search for a Moon-Scaled Koi.

Dialogue.NPCText: "I will await your return beneath the moon’s gaze. Fish with patience and poetry in your heart."

Bozu gazes out at the shimmering surface.
"Some nights, lanterns drift where the water runs deepest. Some say spirits dance there. Others whisper of a sunken cave, its door sealed by riddle and current."
"Fisherfolk vanish, and return speaking only in riddles. The lake keeps its secrets well."

Option.text: I will keep an eye open. Thank you.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"Aye. The old cave opens for those who bring an offering of river pearls—gathered at dawn, when the mist is thickest. Place them on the stone altar, and the waters part."
[Clue: Find river pearls at dawn, offer at lake cave altar]

Bozu’s eyes glint.
"The lakebed is riddled with tunnels, some say reaching all the way to the sea. Beware: spirits dwell in the dark, and not all crave poetry."
"But… within those caves, I once glimpsed a stone lantern that was older than Hinokami itself. If you are brave and quiet, perhaps you will see it too."

Option.text: How do I survive the spirits?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Bozu bows his head.
"Carry a bell of bronze and a poem in your heart. Spirits respect music and memory. And should you lose your way, listen for the song of frogs—follow it home."

Bozu taps his bucket.
"Fish are cleverer than bandits. I could use a steady hand to mend nets, gather bait, or—if you have courage—explore the sunken cave for lost trinkets. Are you willing?"

Option.text: I will mend nets and gather bait.
Tell me more about the sunken cave.

Dialogue.NPCText: "Take this spool and basket. Return when the nets are mended, and I will share a poem for your patience. Sometimes, patience itself is its own reward."

Bozu motions you to sit by the water.
"True fishing is not about the catch. It is the stillness within the self. Sit, breathe, and let the world pass through you like water through reeds."
"Would you like to learn the art of lakeside meditation?"

Option.text: I already know how to meditate.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"Close your eyes. Inhale… exhale… Let your thoughts drift like leaves upon water."
[You feel calmer. Your Meditation has increased!]

Bozu bows with respect.
"Then you already walk the fisher’s path. May your heart be as calm as the deepest pool."

Bozu adjusts his straw hat, eyes fixed on the lake.

"You honor an old man by asking. My story is simple, yet tangled like old netting. I came to Hinokami with nothing but a rod and the grief of war."
"Would you hear more of my past, or of the things I have come to love?"

Option.text: Tell me why you left Tokuno.
What do you love most about fishing?
Have you ever fought in battle?
I think that’s enough for now.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"Tokuno was once calm, like a summer tide. But Minax's horrors came like a storm. My village fell. I lost my brothers and my son to her blood-maddened creatures."

"I left not from cowardice—but because I would not teach the next generation to hate. I chose fish and poems instead of vengeance."
"Do you think that was weakness?"

Option.text: No. Walking away takes greater strength.
I understand why you did it.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Bozu nods slowly, smiling just a little.
"Then I am not alone in this world. Thank you."
"If you ever find yourself filled with anger, sit by still waters and remember this moment."

Bozu lowers his gaze.
"A sharp blade cuts the enemy… but it also dulls the soul. Still, I do not judge. War has its place. So too does the quiet afterward."

Option.text: Perhaps we both chose what we needed.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Bozu casts a pebble into the lake.
"Fishing is not about the fish. It is about listening. Waiting. Feeling the thread of the world tug ever so slightly."
"It teaches humility, patience, and gratitude. That is why I offer fish a poem—not because they are prey, but because they are teachers."
"Would you like a line of your own to carry?"

Option.text: Yes. Please, compose something for me.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Bozu draws brush to paper and murmurs:

'Drifting with purpose,
silent walker beside reeds—
destiny in stillness.'

[You feel strangely calm.]

"My father was a rice farmer. He spoke little. But when the rains came, he’d carve short poems into bamboo. That was his way of praying."
"When the storms took him, I found those verses. Since then, I have written… so I do not forget."
"Even silence, written well, can outlive steel."

Option.text: May I see one of your poems?
That’s beautiful. Thank you for sharing.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Bozu offers a scroll sealed with lakewater ink.

'A blade left to rust,
now reflects the morning light.
Peace sharpens anew.'

"Take it. Copy it if you wish. Just don’t sell it to a trader in Nujel’m, eh?"

"I was once a spearman. Not a good one. I shook too much, and my arms hated killing."
"But one day, I stood between a monster and a mother carrying her child. I did not shake then."

"Since then, I’ve never claimed to be a warrior—but I know courage. You seem to have your own battles. Do you?"

Option.text: I avoid battle when I can.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"Then may your blade be swift, and your conscience steady. Remember: fight monsters… but don’t become one."
"Should you ever need a quiet place to remember yourself, my pier is yours."

Option.text: Thank you. That means more than you know.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Bozu smiles deeply.
"Even one warrior laying down their blade ripples through the world. You bring balance in ways few ever see. Peacekeeper or soldier, walk your path with grace."
